item.title: Composition Process
item.description:
Composition is a large part of my Taiko Journey that I ’ve only recently embarked on. I’ve learned from many teachers what composition is and have gotten into composing myself: on my DAW, Taiko, or for my ensemble Jiten Daiko. Here’s my favorite advice I find myself thinking about a lot.

Just start Link to heading

Don’t be delicate about the composition process. It’s just like writing a diary entry to typing out a sentence. There will be so many half-baked ideas that you will be unable to count them. Find something you like and move on when you’re bored. Stick around and work on ideas when you like them. [Shoji, Kris Bergstrom]

item.title: Elements of Taiko Sound
item.description:
The sound of the Taiko brings many people to it. Here’s a mini-session I taught Jiten Daiko on how I think about the sounds coming from Taiko. Hopefully I can prove these things that I have empircally found using some modeling (Bessel functions and waves on a boundary!) but we’ll see if I find the time.

Breaking down the Sound Link to heading

Thinking about the shape of a waveform and given the fact that we use the same instruments/bachi, I believe we can really only control the attack, the tail, and the chorus. Perhaps the perceived volume is independent of that but I have yet to see if I can control them all separately.

item.title: Composition: Hyakujyuu no Ou
item.description:
Background Link to heading

Hyakujyuu no Ou is the first song composed for and by Columbia University Taiko. It is a celebration of Taiko in New York featuring our strengths of athletic Yokouchi (horizontal playing) playing and set (Dimitri Godur). It utilizes Hachijo style Taiko like movements on a lower stand, inspired both by Hayashi Eitetsu’s Umi no Houjou and KODO’s rendition of Miyake

item.title: Composition: JackBeat
item.description: Short Piece with parts of Jack Bazaar By Kris Bergstrom.

item.title: Composition: Umihure
item.description:
Structure Link to heading

  1. Intro
  2. Fure + Going On + Fure
  3. Right Hand Space
  4. Left Hand Space
  5. Split
  6. Fure + Going On
  7. Mix
  8. Ending

Tutorials Link to heading

item.title: Composition: Zubon
Teaching Taiko
item.description:
I have taught many times over my years of playing Taiko. There’s always difficulties surrounding teaching when it comes to (1) teaching according to people’s levels, (2) not overloading students with details, (3) making it fun.

Teaching towards your students Link to heading

Each student has their own collection of experiences. Some have taiko experiences, others have musical or dance training, and some have no experiences at all. While its often difficult trying to find a way to teach every student in a class, there is usually always some rudimentary skills that even veterans need to drill and always some territory of taiko that the student has yet to see. Mixing fundamentals with new-ness always rounds up a class well.

Thoughts on my playing

  • Keep arms up the entire time, looks lazy
  • Left hand is moving before the hit, makign it weaker
  • Look up more, use head more
  • Get lower and closer to the drum
  • Bounce less

item.title: Dec 2021 LA Trip
item.description: From December 3rd to December 12th, 2021 I was back in LA doing private lessons and learning Taiko. This time I was here for a specific reason: Recital + Concert! I took Yuta Kato’s Yodan Uchi class, Manman’s Quitiplas in the Pocket, and Isaku Kageyama’s Rei so that I could perform them in person at the biannual LATI Recial and the “Art of Taiko” Concert. My week was full with learning Taiko, meeting new Taiko people, and reconnecting with some old ones. A breakdown of what happened.

item.title: LATI Presents: Quitiplas in the Pocket
item.description:
Piece: Quitiplas in the Pocket

ManMan studied Quitiplas (ki-ti-pla) with Venezuelan artist Jackeline Rago in 2013. This music was originally created by the enslaved African-Venezuelan incorporating bamboo sticks when their drums were destroyed and banned by the enslavers. The polyrhythm in quitiplas celebrates freedom of expression and creates a musical conversation that builds community. Empowered by the essence of quitiplas, this taiko piece celebrates the joy of diversity in musical expression.

item.title: June 2021 LA Trip
item.description:
I visited LA in the week of June 5th to June 12th and had a blast! A few awesome Taiko things that happened:

  • Stayed in Kris Bergstrom and Minh Nguyen’s apartment and did jam sessions at his studio!
  • Participated in a UnitOne practice with Jen Baik, Young Kang, Fred Visaya, and Yuta Kato
  • Took a Hachijo and Odaiko/Naname/Yodan private lesson with Yuta Kato
  • Took an Odaiko private lesson with Isaku Kageyama
  • Took a Naname private lesson with Yeeman “Manman” Mui

My trip to LA was the first time I took a private lesson and the first time I felt I was making a step twoard progressing my Taiko skills and training in a meaninful way. It was exhilarating talking to professionals who heard every nerdy thought I had about Taiko and consider them with complete consideration and seriousness. I learned about artist expression, performance mind-set, odaiko soloing, the boundary between music and taiko, and the limitations of my own playing. Can’t wait to go back!

item.title: CU Taiko Presents: Omiyage
item.description:
Finished my last piece with Columbia University Taiko playing Omiyage as taught online by Yuta Kato. Soloists in order are Judy, Isaac, Nathan, Koh. My solo was inspired by the Lefty Roam section of Jack Bazaar by Kris Bergstrom.

Piece: Omiyage by Shoji Kameda

Performers: - Judy Chiu - Nathan Kiesman - Serena Luo - Isaac Loomis - Kohtaro Yamakawa

item.title: Freeing The Beat: The Way toward Open Taiko
item.description:
A proposal to solve a problem I find myself in.

There is a awkward-nesss in American Taiko. When someone tries to join a Taiko group, it is an investment in time and energy. There is no established canon1 that you immediately play with this new group. You usually don’t know their repertoire. For the state of Taiko in America, where most groups only meet once a week, it is hard to join a group without investing a good deal of effort— as it should be! Taiko Groups are founded on the idea of long term investments and community.

item.title: LATI Presents: The Art and Study of Taiko
item.description:
Learned and performed Jack Bazaar as part of Asano Taiko’s Virtual Recital. Had fun meeting Taiko enthusiasts from all over the world (Los Angeles, Berkeley, Little Rock, Calgary, Kawasaki, Buenos Aires) through online asynchronous lessons with Yuta Kato. I believe this was Asano Taiko/LATI’s first venture into complete virtual instruction.

Piece: Jack Bazaar by Kris Bergstrom

Performers: - Helen Mcmillan - Hiromi Ashmore - Marty Hilchey - Stacey Nakasone - Marina Roo - Kohtaro Yamakawa

item.title: Starting a Taiko site
item.description:
Under inspiration from the superb personal site of Kris Bergstrom, I’ll start curating my first personal site on Taiko. I don’t aim really to give any instruction or information to any students but I might post some useful links and thoughts that I’ve had on my Taiko journey!

Documenting and publishing, albeit to an audience of measure zero, is a process that I want to immerse myself in both so that I can look back on my own progress in the future and maybe even organize my thoughts.

item.title: Taiko as Music and Form
item.description: I recall the words of Tsuji Tasuku, member of Eitetsu Fuunkai: “If you play Taiko like a drumset, why don’t you use a drumset instead?” He didn’t mean that all Taiko pieces need to be loud, but that something about the Taiko must be essential to its playing. Indeed, utilizing nagado daiko, shime, or uchiwa to create a backbeat that is replaceable with a western drum set with the same effect, feels like a waste. But, if the appeal of a rhythm or piece necessitates the timbre, choreography, and gravitas of the Taiko, can you be satisfied by saying, “There, it’s Taiko-ness has been utilized. We have checked off that box and can proceed to creating of art without worry”. Doesn’t that feel just as uncomfortable?
